Award.AbstractNarration:
Aggression takes a tremendous toll on society, and it is vital to learn how people may withhold their aggressive impulses. Unfortunately, people seem to have fewer and less effective techniques for controlling aggression than for controlling other emotional impulses. A key problem is that popular strategies for reducing aggression tend to be least effective in the heat of the moment, when tempers can flare. The proposed research introduces a new motivational approach that circumvents this problem. This work will contribute towards the development of more efficient methods for reducing aggression. This is critically important, as aggression reduction is instrumental in preventing countless acts of violence, ranging from domestic violence to aggravated assault and homicide.

The proposed research will target aggressive impulses directly. Prior research has shown that aggressive impulses are characterized by a strong drive towards approach actions, for instance, to blurt out an insulting remark or to hit someone. By blocking this motivation towards approach actions, it may be possible to lower people's impulse to aggress. The proposed research will systematically investigate these motivational influences, and will test whether experimentally manipulating avoidance (versus approach) motivation can reduce the impact of factors that are known to increase aggression, including alcohol, the male sex hormone testosterone, and exposure to media violence. In addition, the proposed research will develop a training program that is geared towards reducing the motivation to aggress. It is expected that lowering approach motivation will particularly reduce aggression among angry individuals who are driven by their impulses and, thus, otherwise most likely to aggress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aggression takes a tremendous toll on society. Anger is the primary cause of aggressive behavior. Unfortunately, people are not very skilled at managing their angry feelings and aggressive impulses. When people are surveyed about how they control their emotions, they typically report that they have fewer and less effective techniques for controlling anger than for controlling other emotions. Anger management represents a daunting task for many people. When anger is intense and expressed in a hostile manner, it may escalate into aggression. Effective anger management is therefore a crucial step in reducing aggression.

 

People who try to control their anger may be metaphorically likened to a cowhand who tries to ride a wild horse. One approach is to help the cowhand improve his or her riding skills. This has been the traditional approach to anger management—teaching people skills to control their anger. However, people often have extreme difficulty controlling their anger in the heat of the moment, when tempers can flare. A different solution is to tame the horse. This research focuses on taming the horse by promoting anger management through the reduction of the person’s aggressive impulses.

 

This research tested a new theoretical approach, the Aggressive Impulse Management (AIM) model, which seeks to promote anger management by reducing a person’s aggressive impulses directly. Prior research has shown that aggressive impulses are characterized by a strong drive towards approach actions, for instance, to blurt out an insulting remark or to hit someone. Angry people are often “in your face.” By blocking this motivation towards approach actions, it may be possible to lower people’s impulse to aggress.

 

This research systematically investigated these motivational influences, and tested whether experimentally manipulating avoidance (versus approach) motivation can reduce angry feelings and aggressive impulses. For example, we found that something as simple as leaning backwards can make people less angry (compared to leaning forward or sitting up straight). However, there is an important caveat: Avoidance motivation only reduce anger and aggression for people who are temperamentally angry. More even-tempered people do not show more anger management when they are led to be more avoidance-oriented.

 

We also examined whether training people to associate angry faces with avoidance movements can promote anger management. This was indeed the case, but again, only among temperamentally angry people. These findings suggest that avoidance training may provide a new anger management intervention that is most effective for people who struggling to control their temper in everyday life.
